text: Chest pain with pressure, crushing, or squeezing sensation, especially with radiation to arm, jaw, neck, or back requires immediate evaluation. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath, nausea, sweating, dizziness. May indicate heart attack, aortic dissection, or pulmonary embolism. Call 911 immediately.

Sudden severe shortness of breath, especially after travel, surgery, or prolonged immobility may indicate pulmonary embolism. Difficulty speaking in full sentences, blue lips or fingernails, or gasping for air requires immediate emergency care. Any breathing difficulty with chest pain is a medical emergency.

FAST signs of stroke: Face drooping (ask person to smile, check if one side droops), Arms weakness (ask person to raise both arms, one drifts down), Speech difficulty (slurred, strange words, confusion), Time to call emergency services immediately. Additional signs include sudden severe headache, sudden vision loss, sudden loss of balance.

Mild tension headaches can be managed with rest in quiet, dark room, adequate hydration, cold or warm compress to head, and over-the-counter pain relievers following package directions. Maintain regular sleep schedule and manage stress. Seek medical care for sudden severe headache, headache with fever and stiff neck, or vision changes.

Common cold symptoms include runny nose, sneezing, mild cough, sore throat, and low-grade fever. Most colds resolve in 7-10 days without treatment. Home care includes rest, fluids, honey for cough (not for infants under 1 year), saline nasal rinses, and pain relievers for adults. Seek medical care if fever exceeds 103째F, symptoms worsen after day 7, or difficulty breathing develops.

Back pain lasting more than 4-6 weeks, recurring episodes, or pain interfering with daily activities may require a non-urgent appointment with a clinician. Seek urgent care if accompanied by fever, numbness in the groin, new weakness in legs, or loss of bladder/bowel control.

Cough lasting more than 3 weeks warrants medical evaluation to rule out underlying conditions. Most acute coughs from viral infections resolve in 2-3 weeks. Schedule appointment for persistent cough, especially with blood in sputum, unexplained weight loss, night sweats, or in smokers over 40. Immediate care needed for cough with severe breathing difficulty or high fever.

Severe bleeding that soaks through bandage in minutes, spurting blood, or bleeding that won't stop after 10-15 minutes of direct pressure requires emergency care. Apply firm direct pressure with clean cloth, elevate injured area above heart if possible, do not remove embedded objects. Call 911 for arterial bleeding, large wounds, or bleeding with signs of shock.

Minor cuts and scrapes can be treated at home with proper first aid. Clean hands, stop bleeding with direct pressure, clean wound with water, apply antibiotic ointment if available, cover with bandage. Watch for signs of infection: increased pain, redness, swelling, warmth, pus, or red streaking. Change bandage daily and keep wound clean and dry.

Fever in infants under 3 months (temperature 100.4째F/38째C or higher) requires immediate medical evaluation as immune systems are immature and serious infections can progress rapidly. For infants 3-6 months, fever over 102째F warrants urgent care. Always measure temperature rectally in infants. Signs requiring emergency care include lethargy, poor feeding, inconsolable crying, rash, difficulty breathing, or blue lips.
